Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 4: Handling & Storage of Hazardous Materials & Appropriate Disposal of Bio-contaminants 

Why are children so vulnerable to damage from toxins?

So, why are children so vulnerable to damage from toxins?

  • Children are in a Dynamic State of Growth and Development

    We need to remember that children are not just “little adults”. They are growing at a tremendous rate. Their nervous, respiratory, reproductive, and immune systems are also developing. Therefore, these systems are more vulnerable to permanent and irreversible damage from toxicants, than a mature system would be.

  • Children’s Ability to Detoxify and Excrete Toxins Differs from Adults

    Young children’s biochemical systems are still developing so their ability to detoxify and excrete toxins differs from adults. Occasionally this may work to their advantage, but normally it results in children not being able to excrete toxins like adults, making them more vulnerable.

  • The Degree, Route of Exposure, and Timing All Impact Effects

    The amount of toxin that is taken in by a child affects the severity of the results. Children can be poisoned through ingestion (by mouth), absorption (through their skin), and inhalation (through their breath). Each of these can have an impact on the effect of the exposure. Timing plays a big role in the results also. For example, exposure as a fetus can result in more damage than a later life exposure. Also, the type of defect seen is highly dependent on the timing of exposure.
